entry.title: Grades and Final Exam Info
entry.content:
All homework and quiz scores are now posted in the Catalyst grade book. The final exam and class grade will be posted some time in the next few days. If you have any questions about your grade, send me an email.

If you want to pick up your exam or any of the old homework or quizzes, you can come to my office on Monday, June 11, between 10:00 to 12:00. You can also come to my office any time before December. Come during office hours (which will be posted on this site) or send me an email to make sure I’ll be around.

Have a good summer.

entry.title: Answers to last makeup quiz
entry.content: Here are the answers to the quiz.

entry.title: Answers to Laplace transforms worksheet
entry.content: Here are the answers to the worksheet we did in class today.

entry.title: Accelerometers
entry.content: Using only math that you’ve learned this quarter, Dr. Drang explains how accelerometers work in a blog post this weekend. Check it out.

entry.title: Quiz 6
entry.content: Your last new quiz of the quarter will be on Friday, May 25. You will have to solve a full (but simple) piecewise differential eqaution using Laplace transforms. All Laplace formulas will be printed on the quiz. You may use a calculator but no notes.

entry.title: [Lesson 9W] Laplace transforms of discontinuous functions
entry.content:
A start-to-finish example of a differential equation with a discontinuous function. Section 6.4.

View the lesson

entry.title: Schedule for Week 8
entry.content:
Things will be a little different for Week 8 from what they normally are.

  • There will be no class on Friday, May 18.
  • The quiz will be on Wednesday, May 16, instead of Friday. It will cover sections 6.1 and 6.2. I do not expect you to memorize any Laplace transform formulas.
  • There will be no office hours on Wednesday or Friday. Please email me any questions you have.

entry.title: [Lesson 7F] Using Laplace Transforms
entry.content:
Using Laplace transforms to solve initial value problems. Section 6.1.

View the lesson

entry.title: Answers to resonance worksheet
entry.content: Here are the answers to the resonance worksheet that we did in class today.

entry.title: Quiz 4
entry.content: The fourth quiz of the quarter will be given on Friday, May 11. It will cover sections 3.5 and 3.8.

entry.title: Midterm grades
entry.content: The median score on the midterm was 31. Here is a histogram of the scores.

entry.title: [Lesson 7M] Forced oscillation and resonance
entry.content:
An introduction to resonance and forced oscillation. Section 3.8.

View the lesson

entry.title: [Lesson 6F] Undetermined coefficients, part 2
entry.content:
How to find the format for the particular solution, and when and how to “bump up” the particular solution. Section 3.5.

View the lesson

entry.title: [Lesson 6W] Method of Undetermined Coefficients
entry.content:
The method of undetermined coefficients lets you solve non-homogeneous linear differential equations. Section 3.5.

View the lesson

entry.title: Answers to the makeup quiz
entry.content:
The answers to the makeup quiz are posted (Now updated).

Good luck on the Midterm Exam.

entry.title: [Lesson 5F] Analyze damped oscillation
entry.content:
This is a quick lesson discussing how to analyze damped oscillations. Section 3.7.

View the lesson

entry.title: Exam details
entry.content:
You may use up to 5 pages of notes (printed or written on both sides) on the exam. You may use a non graphing calculator.

The problems on the exams will be more difficult than the quiz questions, in the same way that the homework problems from the end of the sections are more difficult than the homework problems from the beginning of the sections. Some exams from a previous quarter are on the exams page.

The midterm exam will be in class on Monday, April 30.

entry.title: [Lesson 5W] Trigonometry review
entry.content:
Use trigonometry identities to combine sine and cosines into a single term. Some terminology: frequency, amplitude, quasi frequency, etc. Section 3.7.

View the lesson

entry.title: Instructions for the make up quiz
entry.content:
The makeup quiz will be given on Friday. There will be a single quiz with three problems. You must choose one problem to do.

  • The first problem will be from section 2.1 or 2.2. If you do this problem, your score will replace the score you got on Quiz 1.
  • The second problem will be from section 2.4 or 2.5. If you do this problem, your score will replace the score you got on Quiz 2.
  • The third problem will be from section 3.1 or 3.3. If you do this problem, your score will replace the score you got on Quiz 3.

If you do worse on the make up quiz than you did on the original quiz, I will not change your score.

The quiz will be given the last 15 minutes of class. If you do not want to take the makeup quiz, you can leave at that point.

entry.title: Mid-quarter survey
entry.content: I would appreciate any feedback from students currently enrolled in the course. Please take this mid-quarter survey.

entry.title: [Lesson 4W] Complex Roots to the Characteristic Equation
entry.content:
Although the method from Monday technically works even if the roots to the characteristic equation are not real, there is a way to eliminate the imaginary numbers by using sines and cosines. Section 3.3.

View the lesson

entry.title: Third Quiz
entry.content: The third quiz will be given on Friday, April 20 in class. It will cover sections 3.1 and 3.3.

entry.title: [Lesson 4M] Linear Homogeneous equations with constant coefficients
entry.content:
Second order linear homogeneous differential equations, with constant coefficients. They are pretty easy to solve, and you don't have to do any integration. Section 3.1.

View the lesson

entry.title: Cooling Worksheet
entry.content: You can now read the solutions to the worksheet on Newton’s law of cooling that we worked on in class today.

entry.title: Second Quiz
entry.content: Your second quiz will be given Friday, April 13 at the beginning of class. You may use a calculator but no notes. The quiz will cover sections 2.4 and 2.5.

entry.title: [Lesson 3W] Euler's Method
entry.content:
Euler's method uses the tangent line approximation to find an approximate solution for first order differential equations that you cannot solve in other ways. Section 2.7.

View the lesson

entry.title: [Lesson 3M] Autonomous equations
entry.content:
An autonomous equation is a differential equation that depends only on y and y', and not on t. You can understand these without solving the differential equation by finding the equilibrium solutions. Section 2.5.

View the lesson

entry.title: Hints for Homework 1
entry.content:
In 2.1.30, the solution to the differential equation has an e^t term. The only way for the initial value problem to remain finite as t goes to infinity is if the initial value causes this term to disappear.

For 2.2.27, you can use a slope field to answer part (a). You will need to solve the differential equation for part (b). You will want to use partial fractions to do the integration when solving the differential equation.

For 2.3.19, you will probably have a better chance of being correct if you write a differential equation for Q'(t) and not for c'(t).

entry.title: First Quiz
entry.content: Your first quiz will be given Friday, April 6 at the beginning of class. You may use a calculator but no notes. The quiz will be a single question from the material covered in the homework from sections 2.1 and 2.2. You will have 10-15 minutes.

entry.title: [Lesson 2W] Modeling credit card interest
entry.content:
More modeling problems. This lesson is a discussion of the credit card interest problem that we did in class. Section 2.3.

View the lesson

entry.title: [Lesson 2M] Modeling a tank with dyed water
entry.content:
A first example of modeling with differential equations. Many problems are similar to the tank problem, where you have to account for how much of something is flowing in and how much is flowing out. Section 2.3.

View the lesson

entry.title: [Lesson 1F] Integrating Factors
entry.content:
The method of integrating factors helps you solve first order linear differential equations. You have to integrate with respect to t two times in order to solve each problem. Section 2.1.

View the lesson

entry.title: [Lesson 1W] Separable differential equations
entry.content:
Solve separable first-order differential equations by separating the variables and integrating both sides of the equation. Section 2.2 from the book.

View the lesson

entry.title: Draw a slope field
entry.content: Here is the slope field generator I mentioned in class today. It may help you as you do your homework. Slope fields are a great way to visual first order differential equations. I wrote the program recently, so if you run into a bug, send me an email.

entry.title: [Lesson 1M] First day of class
entry.content:
Classifying differential equations (linear, homogeneous, etc.) and mathematical modeling. This is material we covered the first day of class, and is found in Chapter 1 of the textbook.

View the lesson

entry.content:
This feed will contain all announcements posted to this page.

You can subscribe to the feed in Google Reader, receive email updates via blogtrottr, or use your favorite news aggregator.

entry.title: Welcome to the class
entry.content: Welcome to my Math 307 class. Here is the syllabus.
